item.title: ‘Marty Supreme’ Review: Timothée Chalamet Sprints to the Top
item.description: The actor stars as a magnetic, striving table-tennis champ in Josh Safdie’s new movie, one of the most exciting movies of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Timothée Chalamet in “Marty Supreme,” set in 1952 New York and directed by Josh Safdie with electrifying flourish.

item.title: ‘No Other Choice’ Review: A Company Man Cut Loose
item.description: Park Chan-wook, the director of “Oldboy” and “The Handmaiden,” brings comedic flair to the cruel tale of an employee pushed to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The Testament of Ann Lee’ Review: A Woman Clothed With the Sun
item.description: In an extraordinary performance, Amanda Seyfried plays the founder of the Shakers in a singular film.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: From ‘Splitsville’ to ‘Friendship,’ the Year’s Best Fight Scenes
item.description: Everywhere you looked this year, men were feuding. In movies like “Splitsville,” “Eddington” and “Friendship,” it was gloriously pathetic.
item.dc:creator: Max Cea

item.title: ‘Song Sung Blue’ Review: A Christmas ‘Caroline’
item.description: Craig Brewer’s toe-tapping weepie about the triumphs and tragedies of a Neil Diamond tribute band is exactly the movie we need right now.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Goodbye June’ Review: Terms of Endearment, and Estrangement
item.description: Kate Winslet directs a formulaic script by her son, Joe Anders, about a dying matriarch and her quarreling adult children.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘Anaconda’ Review: Back in the Jungle
item.description: The movie gets at least one thing right: Rebooting the shlocky, widely-panned creature-feature, starring Jack Black and Paul Rudd, is a goofy idea.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘Sinners,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and the Art of Racial Solidarity
item.description: Across film (“Sinners,” “One Battle After Another”), theater (“Ragtime”) and TV (“The Lowdown”), four works suggested what achieving racial equality in America would take.
item.dc:creator: Salamishah Tillet

item.title: Did We Underestimate Kate Hudson?
item.description: For years she was pigeonholed as a rom-com star. Her turn as a blue-collar mom with a love of Neil Diamond just might vault her back to the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Thea Traff

item.title: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Timothée Chalamet in “Marty Supreme,” set in 1952 New York and directed by Josh Safdie with electrifying flourish.

item.title: The Ping-Pong Hustler Who Inspired ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: Volleying questions with the table tennis champ Marty Reisman, an inspiration for Timothée Chalamet’s new film, showed that he was a character in his own right.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Donald F. Holway/The New York Times
item.media:description: Marty Reisman won 22 major table tennis titles over the course of a colorful career.

item.title: ‘The Choral’ Review: Singing to Keep the Fear at Bay
item.description: As England goes to war, a provincial choir master played by Ralph Fiennes is challenged to find available voices in this poignant drama set in 1916.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘The Plague’ Review: Pool of the Flies
item.description: A stunner of a debut film follows a group of boys at a water polo camp, where an outsider is just trying to fit in.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Father Mother Sister Brother’ Review: Families, Untied
item.description: Jim Jarmusch’s uneven triptych, a prizewinner at Venice, saves its best segment for last.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Robert Nakamura, ‘Godfather’ of Asian American Film, Dies at 88
item.description: In his work, he often returned to Manzanar, the camp in which he and his family, along with thousands of other people of Japanese descent, were interned during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Russell Brand Is Charged With Additional Counts of Rape and Sexual Assault
item.description: The actor, comedian and YouTuber now faces seven counts of rape and sexual assault in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Russell Brand at a London courthouse in May.

item.title: ‘The Queen of Versailles’ Bombed on Broadway. What Went Wrong?
item.description: The show reunited Kristin Chenoweth and Stephen Schwartz for the first time since “Wicked.” It wasn’t enough to counter poor word of mouth and other challenges.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: “The Queen of Versailles,” which opened at the St. James Theater on Nov. 9, was adapted from Lauren Greenfield’s 2012 documentary about a couple seeking to build a palatial home in Florida.

item.title: 7 Takeaways From the Final Episodes of Taylor Swift’s ‘The End of an Era’
item.description: Seven takeaways from the final episodes of “The End of an Era,” the Disney+ series exploring her globe-trotting concert extravaganza.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times

item.title: The Best Animated Shows and Movies of 2025
item.description: Yes, “KPop Demon Hunters” makes the list. But that was just one of the standouts in a great year.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘Jingle All the Way,’ and the Super Bad Dad Superhero
item.description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sinbad, Phil Hartman and Rita Wilson served a platter of high-octane holiday high jinks in this unhinged 1996 comedy.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Kate Winslet’s Unhappy Family Christmas
item.description: The British actress’s directorial debut, “Goodbye June,” is based on a script written by her son and follows a fractured family reuniting in the hospital over the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Thea Traff
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: May Britt, 91, Dies; Her Marriage to Sammy Davis Jr. Sparked Outrage
item.description: She was a white actress, he was a popular Black entertainer, and their relationship elicited racist reactions in 1960, worrying John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Ms. Britt and Mr. Davis at their wedding in November 1960. It was reported that the event had been delayed from October at the request of John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign to avoid negative attention before the election.

item.title: Artists We Lost in 2025, in Their Words
item.description: Robert Redford, Roberta Flack, Diane Keaton and Brian Wilson are among the cultural luminaries who died this year.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Cohn
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Neal Boenzi/The New York Times; Fairchild Archive/Penske Media, via Getty Images; Jack Robinson/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images; Sara Hirakawa for The New York Times; Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Robert Redford, Diane Keaton, Roberta Flack, David Lynch, and Brian Wilson.

item.title: Review: A ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’ Musical Is a Psychedelic Parable
item.description: At Greenwich House Theater, Greta Gertler Gold and Hilary Bell’s stage adaptation of Joan Lindsay’s novel hovers between reverie and reality.
item.dc:creator: Brittani Samuel
item.category: Picnic at Hanging Rock: The Musical (Play)
item.media:description: From left: Kate Louissant, Gillian Han, Tatianna Córdoba and Carly Gendell at the Greenwich House Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Sydney Sweeney’s Offscreen Image Contrasts With Progressive Onscreen Roles
item.description: Onscreen, she tends to play women fighting the patriarchy; offscreen the image she cultivates has meant conservatives consider her one of their own.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: As the ‘Avatar’ Villain Varang, Oona Chaplin Blazes Her Own Fiery Path
item.description: She had been working with refugees and channeled her anger over their situation into the ferocious performance, which was filmed several years ago.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh

item.title: What We Know About Rob Reiner’s Final Projects
item.description: The release of a “Spinal Tap” concert film that was filmed at Stonehenge has been delayed.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.category: Spinal Tap at Stonehenge: The Final Finale (Movie)

item.title: Theodor Pistek, 93, Oscar-Winning ‘Amadeus’ Costume Designer, Dies
item.description: He worked on more than 100 films, but that wasn’t all: He was also a racecar driver and a painter of photorealistic works, many depicting cars.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Theodor Pistek in 2017. A racecar driver, artist and costume designer, he was best known for creating clothes for two Milos Forman films set in the 18th century, “Amadeus” and “Valmont.”

item.title: Carrie Coon and Tracy Letts Want to Get Under Your Skin
item.description: The couple are gearing up for the Broadway opening of “Bug,” about a descent into paranoia and psychosis in a squalid motel room.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:credit: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, torrents, trolls and time travel.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream
item.description: The final column of the year looks at the end of things — the end of the world, the end of youth — along with an underrated holiday gem.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Avatar: Fire and Ash’: What to Remember Before Seeing the New Movie
item.description: The newest chapter in the saga of the Na’vi people continues to build their highly detailed world. Here’s a guide to catch you up on the developments.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants (Movie)

item.title: ‘Sorry, Baby,’ ‘Lurker’ and the Year’s Great Under-the-Radar Streaming Films
item.description: Here are just a few of the year’s finest indies, documentaries and international selections, available to stream at this very minute.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: ‘Breakdown: 1975’ Remembers the Cinematic Voices of an Era
item.description: This documentary could be better, but it offers a helpful lesson for film fans new to the movies of that decade.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
